Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Boris L. Hanin is "Gaussian Random Functions in the Semiclassical Limit." The host institution for the fellowship is the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Alice Guionnet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is the Project Outcomes Report for DMS-1400822, which was an NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship executed between from September 2014 to June 2017 by the PI at the MIT Department of Mathematics. In the course of this Postdoctoral Fellowship, the PI produced seven articles on topics in the fields of spectral theory, probability, and partial differential equations, along the lines proposed in the project description for the grant. Specifically, the PI, together with collaborator Y. Canzani, wrote three articles on the scaling limit of the spectral projector of the Laplacian on a compact Riemannian manifold. The purpose of these articles was the understand the relationship between quantum and classical mechanics (the so-called correspondence principle) in simple case of a single free particle moving along a manifold. The PI also completed, together with collaborators S. Zelditch and P. Zhou, an article about the scaling limit of the spectral projector for the quantum harmonic oscillator at the caustic. The harmonic oscillator is among the most important and best understood quantum systems. The article gave new insights into its high behavior at the edge of the classically allowed region, where quantum effects are more pronounced even at high frequencies.

Beyond to these articles on spectral asymptotics, the PI also wrote two articles on zero sets of eigenfunctions. In one article, the PI, together with collaborators T. Beck and S. Becker-Khan, followed through on a proposal of recent articles about minimal surfaces (e.g. soap films suspended between wires) and zeros sets of eigenfunctions for the Laplacian. In the other article, the PI, together with T. Beck, obtained some of the first results about nodal sets of eigenfunctions for the harmonic oscillator deep into the classically forbidden region. Finally, the PI wrote an article about a relationship between zeros and critical points of random polynomials in one complex variable, continuing a series of articles from the PI’s PhD.

In addition to writing the seven articles described above, the PI traveled extensively to collaborate and give research talks, giving 28 talks in during 2014-17. The PI also refereed six articles for professional journals, and, while at MIT, helped organize the probability seminar.
